entry.title: Combined summary - Mailing List Future
entry.summary:
In a recent exchange among programmers, the focus was on finding a sustainable and reliable platform for future discussions. Concerns were raised about the longevity of the current http://delvingbitcoin.org/ system, particularly in terms of archivability and authentication. The ease with which email lists can be archived, combined with their inherent ability to support robust authentication methods like PGP and DMARC, makes them a preferable choice for some participants. There was also skepticism expressed about delvingbitcoin.org's ability to offer security beyond basic timestamping.
The group considered various alternatives, including hosting their own mailing list (ML), using groups.io, and adopting a discourse instance. The majority seemed inclined towards trying out delvingbitcoin.org, at least for a trial period. Some members expressed interest in the platform's "mailing list mode," although its reliability was questioned. A follow-up discussion was scheduled to reassess satisfaction with this solution or to consider other options, such as self-hosting a discourse or reverting to a traditional ML setup.
One participant, Vincent, highlighted his willingness to collaborate on a project that employs machine learning moderation, confident in handling any potential spam issues. He suggested that even non-Microsoft email services could effectively manage spam with proper moderation in place. Vincent also proposed hosting the ML himself due to his involvement in other projects requiring similar infrastructure.
Another aspect of the conversation dealt with Google Groups as a potential host for the ML. Users without Gmail accounts can still join these groups through subscription requests or by linking a non-Gmail email to a Google account to access the web interface. However, the inability to use the web UI without a Google account remains a barrier.
Discourse emerged as a favored solution, noted for its visual presentation of images and LaTeX, as well as organizational features such as tags and categories. Its 'email list mode' was particularly appealing for offering a bridge between traditional ML functionalities and modern web-based features.
As the conversation unfolded, it was decided that a vote would take place at the next meeting to finalize the choice of platform. Interested parties were encouraged to attend this meeting or to share their input via email beforehand, ensuring a broad representation of views in the decision-making process.
